children.name: worried
children.definition: not feeling happy or relaxed, because you keep thinking about a problem or about something bad that might happen:

children.name: lo lắng
examples: ▪ Dave could see how worried she was, and he tried to reassure her.

children.name: look worried : trông có vẻ lo lắng
examples: ▪ You look worried - what’s the matter?

children.name: worried about : lo lắng về
examples: ▪ Marion was worried about losing her job.
▪ We’re very worried about Grandma.
▪ I’m not really worried about how much it will cost.

children.name: worried (that) : lo rằng
examples: ▪ She rushed to the station, worried that she might miss her train.
▪ I was worried if I washed it, it might shrink.

children.name: get worried : trở nên lo lắng
examples: ▪ I’m getting worried because my account still hasn’t registered a check I deposited a while ago.

children.name: a worried look/frown/glance etc : vẻ, nét lo lắng
examples: ▪ She had such a worried look on her face!
▪ Helen looked at me with a worried expression.

children.name: nervous
children.definition: worried andslightlyfrightened about something thatis going to happenor somethingnewordifficultthat you have to do:
examples: căng thẳng , hồihộp
▪ I’m always nervous before exams.get nervous
▪ Mum gets nervous if we don’t call to say we’re late.
look/feel/sound nervous
▪ Bill looked nervous, and I could see that his hands were shaking.
▪ Harry began to feel nervous again as the plane made its descent
make somebody (feel) nervous
▪ The sounds outside were making me feel nervous.
▪ Stop tapping your feet! You’re making me nervous.
nervous about
▪ Kelly was so nervous about her interview that she couldn’t sleep.
nervously [adverb]
▪ Nervously, she twisted her handkerchief in her fingers.
▪ Carrie peeped out nervously.

children.name: anxious
children.definition: especiallywrittenvery worried because you think that something bad has happened or may happen, and you feel that you have no control over the situation:
examples: anxiously [adverb]
▪ ‘Is he going to be all right?’ she asked anxiously.

children.name: lo lắng, lo âu ,khắc khoải, trăn trở
examples: ▪ Anxious relatives waited at the airport for news of the plane crash.

children.name: feel/sound anxious :cảm thấy lo lắng
examples: ▪ She knew it was a simple operation, but she still felt anxious.

children.name: anxious about : lo âu về
examples: ▪ Helen is always anxious about travelling alone.
▪ When you become anxious about sleeplessness, you actually make the problem worse.

children.name: an anxious face/voice/expression etc : một vẻ mặt/ giọng nói/ biểu hiện lo âu
examples: ▪ ‘Please come with me,’ she said in an anxious voice.
▪ Mae cast an anxious look in his direction.

children.name: concerned
children.definition: worried about someone else’s problems, health, safety etc:

children.name: lo lắng ( cho ai khác )
examples: ▪ A TV programme about cruelty to children brought hundreds of letters from concerned viewers.

children.name: concerned about
examples: ▪ I’m very concerned about Veronica. She looks so pale, and she has no appetite.
▪ World governments are becoming increasingly concerned about rising global temperature levels.

children.name: concerned for
examples: ▪ Rescuers are concerned for the safety of two men trapped in the mine.

children.name: apprehensive
children.definition: worried and a little frightened about something that you are going to do or about thefuture, because you are not sure what it will be like:
examples: apprehensively[adverb]
▪ She looked at her father apprehensively, frightened of what his reaction would be.

children.name: lo âu ( về tương lai )
examples: ▪ Dr Gottlieb reassures apprehensive patients that the operation is a simple procedure.

children.name: apprehensive about
examples: ▪ I must admit that before my baby was born I was very apprehensive about motherhood.
▪ No one need be apprehensive about their personal safety; everything is under control.

children.name: uneasy
children.definition: worried and not happy with asituation, because you feel there may be somethingwrongand you are not sure what is going to happen:
examples: băn khoăn lo lắng ( cảm thấy có gì bất ổn )
make somebody uneasy
▪ When I answered the telephone, no one was there, which made me uneasy.
feel uneasy
▪ After a while she started to feel uneasy, and then scared.
uneasy about
▪ Roger was a bit uneasy about the plan, but he agreed.
▪ 75 percent of consumers said they were uneasy about using their credit cards over the Internet.
distinctly uneasy
very uneasy
▪ I was distinctly uneasy in his company, but I couldn’t explain why.
have the/an uneasy feeling
▪ She had the uneasy feeling that he wasn’t going to come back.
uneasily[adverb]
▪ Deborah shifted uneasily in her seat.

children.name: dismayed
children.definition: very worried, disappointed, and upset by something thathashappened:

children.name: thất kinh ( về việc gì đã xảy ra )
examples: ▪ Hardeep’s lawyer said his client was ‘shocked and dismayed’ after hearing the court’s decision.

children.name: dismayed at/by
examples: ▪ American historians are dismayed at the condition of the texts stored in the library.

children.name: dismayed to see/hear etc
examples: ▪ We were dismayed to discover that our daughter Louise had started experimenting with heroin.

children.name: dismayed that
examples: ▪ Danby was dismayed that Watt had opposed him in the vote.
▪ Many of the nurses are dismayed that the management intends to make further service reductions.

children.name: not like the look/sound of
children.definition: if you do not like the look or sound of something, it makes you feel worried and unhappy because it seems threatening or dangerous:
examples: không thích cái vẻ ...
▪ I don’t like the look of that rash on your chest.
▪ The captain’s face darkened as he listened. ‘I don’t like the sound of this,’ he said.
▪ Don’t let anyone into your home that you don’t like the look of.

children.name: worry
examples: làm ai lo lắng
▪ The changes in the Earth’s climate began to worry some scientists.
▪ ‘Why didn’t you tell me?’ ‘I didn’t want to worry you.’
it worries somebody that
▪ Doesn’t it worry you that Stephen spends so much time away from home?
what worries somebody is
▪ What worries me is the difference in age between Rosie and her boyfriend.
▪ One thing that worried me was that information had been leaked to the press.

children.name: trouble
children.definition: if a problem troubles you, it makes you feel worried because you do not know what to do about it:
examples: troubled[adjective]
▪ Kemp looked troubled. ‘I’m not sure what’s wrong,’ he said.
▪ He caught her troubled expression, and put an arm around her shoulders.

children.name: làm ai phiền não, lo lắng
examples: ▪ You must talk to your daughter and find out what’s troubling her.
▪ The incident troubled me -- it wasn’t like Sarah to be so secretive.

children.name: be troubled by something
examples: ▪ She is troubled by the fact that her son already shows signs of inheriting his father’s mental problems.

children.name: concern
children.definition: ifsomeoneelse’s problems, health, safety etc concern you, you worry about them because you think they are important, even when they may not affect you personally:

children.name: ( vấn đề của ai đó ) làm ai lo lắng
examples: ▪ Kate’s behaviour at school is starting to concern her parents.

children.name: it concerns somebody that
examples: ▪ It concerns me that some tutors are meeting with students outside college hours.

children.name: what concerns somebody is
examples: ▪ What concerns me most is that despite pay increases, production has not improved.

children.name: bother
children.definition: if something bothers you, it slightly worries you - use this especially about problems that donotseemserious:

children.name: gây phiền hà , quấy rầy
examples: ▪ The only thing that bothers me is how I’m going to get from the station to the farm.
▪ You shouldn’t let little things like that bother you.

children.name: what bothers somebody is
examples: ▪ What bothers me is that you didn’t feel you could talk to me or your father about it.

children.name: cause concern
children.definition: /be a cause for concernalsogive somebody cause for concern  if something thatishappeningcauses concern or is a cause for concern, it makes someone, especially someone in anofficialposition, feel worried, because it is unsatisfactory or possibly dangerous - used especially inofficialsituations:

children.name: gây lo ngại
examples: ▪ We have to inform you that your son’s behaviour has been causing concern for some time now.
▪ Two dozen cases of water poisoning in the space of a week certainly is a cause for concern, and we shall be taking action.
▪ The Secretary General said that the recent developments are giving him cause for concern.

children.name: cause somebody concern
examples: ▪ Your husband has almost recovered -- the only thing that’s still causing us concern is his high blood pressure.

children.name: cause concern among
examples: ▪ The decision has caused concern among human rights groups.

children.name: prey on your mind
children.definition: if a problem or something bad thathashappenedpreys on your mind, it worries youcontinuouslyeven though you do not want to think about it:
examples: ▪ It was starting to prey on my mind so much that I went to the hospital.
▪ The old woman’s warning preyed on Mary’s mind as she continued her journey.

children.name: concern
children.definition: a worried feeling - use this especially whenmanypeopleare worried about a problem thataffectseveryone:

children.name: sự quan ngại , lo lắng ( nhiều người )
examples: ▪ The shortage of water is beginning to cause widespread concern.

children.name: concern about/over
examples: ▪ There is also some concern about the safety of the structure.

children.name: express/voice concern
examples: ▪ I did voice my concern about the financial management, but was told to stay quiet.

children.name: deep/grave concern
examples: ▪ This is a matter of grave concern to the hospital management.

children.name: anxiety
children.definition: the feeling of being worried because you think that something bad has happened or will happen, and you feel that you have no control over the situation:

children.name: mối lo âu , lo lắng
examples: ▪ I knew I had to give a speech, but the thought filled me with anxiety.

children.name: ▪ feelings of guilt and anxiety
examples: ▪ The increase in the tax on heating fuel is causing a lot of anxiety among elderly people.

children.name: anxiety about
examples: ▪ Her anxiety about the pain of childbirth is understandable.

children.name: sự lo lắng, cảm giác lo lắng
examples: ▪ The meningitis outbreak is a major cause of worry at the moment.
▪ The rage and disappointment had disappeared, but the worry in Jim’s face was starting to show.

children.name: worry over/about
examples: ▪ This constant worry about your debts isn’t doing you any good at all.

children.name: be sick with worry : lo lắng đến phát bệnh
examples: ▪ The poor mother was sick with worry over her missing daughter.

children.name: stress
children.definition: the feeling of being worriedall the time, for example about work or personal problems, which can make you ill or very tired:
examples: sự căng thẳng
▪ Her financial problems were causing her a lot of stress.
▪ methods for reducing stress
▪ Air travelers can enjoy stress-free trips if they follow a few guidelines.
stress of
▪ The city’s many parks offer a comforting relief from the stress of modern life.
mental/emotional/psychological stress: căng thẳng thần kinh / cảm xúc/ tâm lý
▪ Geoff is having trouble dealing with the emotional stress of his recent divorce.
stress-related illnesses/disorders/conditions etc : .. căng thẳng đầu óc
illnesses, conditions etc caused by stress
▪ His wife has also suffered stress-related health problems.
be under stress
be feeling stress
▪ She had been under a lot of stress just before the baby was born.
▪ Workers are under such stress right now, and they have less time to spend relaxing with their families.

children.name: strain
children.definition: a feeling of being worried that is caused by having tocontinuouslydeal with a difficult problem or having to work very hard for alongperiodof time:

children.name: sự căng thẳng ( do phải làm việc liên lục thời gian dài )
examples: ▪ The strain of managing such a huge company became too much for Anita.
▪ He could see the strain in her face as she told him what she was going through.

children.name: be a strain on : là gánh nặng cho , đè nặng
examples: ▪ The legal fight has been an enormous strain on my wife.

children.name: put (a) strain on something : đè gánh nặng lên
examples: ▪ The company wanted 110% commitment, and that put a strain on our marriage.

children.name: be under strain : bị gánh nặng
examples: ▪ She had a busy week, and she’s under a lot of strain at the moment.

children.name: angst
children.definition: a strong feeling of worry and anxiety, especially about things that youcannotchange:
examples: lo lắng tuyệt vọng ( về điều gì không thể thay đổi được )
▪ Wallowing in angst about the unfairness of it all will just make the problem worse.
▪ a period of national angst
▪ a touching story of teenage angst

children.name: st that makes you feel worried
worry
examples: mối lo lắng
▪ It’s important that children can discuss their worries with their parents.
▪ His remarks reflect a widespread worry that Canada may be going the same way as the US.
worry about/over
▪ Worries about the tire company’s performance sent its shares tumbling.
▪ The launch was delayed because of worries over protestors.
greatest/biggest/main etc worry
▪ Roosevelt’s chief worry at the time was that an attack on Britain would put the US at a strategic disadvantage

children.name: hang-up
children.definition: if you have a hang-up about something, for example your appearance, or your relationships with other people, you feel worried and embarrassed about it, and thismakes you feel less confident:

children.name: nỗi lo lắng ( về điều gì làm bạn mất tự tin )
examples: ▪ I want the children to understand sex and grow up without any hang-ups.

children.name: have a hang-up about
examples: ▪ Sarah has a hang-up about her nose -- she thinks it’s too big.
▪ They’re just ordinary people with all the usual hang-ups about love.

children.name: concern
children.definition: a situation that makes you feel worried, especially a problem that affectsa lot of people, but that maynotaffect youpersonally:

children.name: mối quan ngại
examples: ▪ The hospital’s main concern is that doctors are overworked.
▪ The survey suggests that rising crime is the top of the average American’s concerns.

children.name: concern about/over
examples: ▪ My only concern about the match is that Price will be fit enough to take part.
▪ The committee brushed aside concerns about racism and prejudice in local government.

children.name: raise concernscause concerns : gây quan ngại
examples: ▪ The incident has raised concerns that the government may retaliate.

children.name: stresses and strains
children.definition: all the things in a job or situation that make you feel worried and tired, especially when your work or life is very difficult:
examples: sự căng thẳng
▪ Despite many stresses and strains, the team has held together, and I’m proud of that.
stresses and strains of
▪ the stresses and strains of modern living
▪ Do some gentle exercises to relieve the stresses and strains of your day.

children.name: cares
children.definition: problems or responsibilities in your life that make you worry:

children.name: mối bận tâm
examples: ▪ She was not really ready for the cares and responsibilities of running a family.
▪ ‘Forget all your cares and worries’, as the song goes.

children.name: relieved
children.definition: feeling relaxedagainbecause you do not need to worry about something that you worried about before:
examples: bớt căng thẳng, lo lắng ( sau khi đã lo lắng )
▪ ‘Oh,’ she said, relieved. ‘I’m so glad you’re back.’
seem/feel/look/appear relieved
▪ The hostages simply look relieved to be going home.
relieved that
▪ I was relieved that John was there to help me explain.
▪ The government will be relieved that a crisis has been averted.
relieved at
▪ Sahlin appeared relieved at my news.
relieved to know/hear/find/learn etc something
▪ I’m so relieved to see you!
▪ Polly was relieved to learn that her mother’s illness was not a serious one.
▪ Andrew was relieved to discover that he was not himself under suspicion.

children.name: relief
children.definition: the pleasant feeling you have when you no longer have to worry about something:
examples: sự bớt căng thẳng
▪ A white envelope lay on the mat. Holmes felt considerable relief.
a feeling/sense of relief
▪ Edwards commented that the convictions give him a feeling of relief that he hopes the victim shares.
with relief
▪ To her own surprise, she began sobbing with relief.
to somebody’s relief : nhẹ cả người
making them feel relieved "
▪ To Greg’s relief, nobody asked to check his ticket.
▪ The rains came this weekend, much to the relief of tomato growers in Florida.
breathe/heave a sigh of relief
show by your behaviour that you are no longer worried about something
▪ You could hear the students breathing a collective sigh of relief when the final bell rang.
it is a relief to know/hear/see/find etc
▪ It was such a relief to see Liz looking healthy again.
▪ Mary says it’s a relief to have someone to talk to at last.
come as a relief
▪ The decision, announced on Thursday, came as a huge relief to the factory’s 300 workers.

children.name: not worried/concerned
children.definition: alsounconcernedformal
examples: không lo lắng
▪ Sam had stayed out late before, so we weren’t particularly worried when he didn’t return.
▪ Brian didn’t seem at all concerned when the car broke down.
not worried/concerned about
▪ He insists that he is not worried about the poor showing his party made in the recent local elections.
▪ For once, Karen seemed unconcerned about the possibility of being late for class.
not in the least bit worried etc : không lo lắng chút nào
not at all worried
▪ Even after losing her job, she doesn’t seem in the least bit worried.

children.name: be a weight off sb’s mind
children.definition: be a weight off somebody’s mind  spoken if something is a weight off your mind you do not have to worry any more because something has happened to make you feel happier about it:
examples: nhẹ cả đầu óc
be a great/big/enormous weight off somebody’s mind
▪ No doubt the news will be a huge weight off his mind.
take a weight off somebody’s mind
▪ Now that Peter has passed all his exams, it’s taken a great weight off my mind.

children.name: not lose sleep over
children.definition: to not be worried by a problem because you do not think it is important enough:
examples: không bị mất ngủ bởi ...
▪ I tried my best, and I certainly won’t be losing any sleep over the result.
▪ It’s not that serious. I wouldn’t lose sleep over it if I were you.

children.name: have no qualms
children.definition: if you have no qualms about something, you are not worried about it, especially because you are sure it is the right thing to do:

children.name: không ngần ngại
examples: have no qualms about :
▪ One protestor said he would have no qualms about bombing the clinic.
▪ He was a man who had no qualms about preaching one thing and practising another in his private life.

children.name: carefree
children.definition: cheerful and not worried about anything, because you do not have any real problems or responsibilities in your life:

children.name: vô tư lự , thảnh thơi
examples: ▪ I felt carefree for the first time in my life.
▪ They both laughed, feeling like two carefree schoolgirls.

children.name: without a care in the world
children.definition: /not have a care in the world  if someone is without a care in the world, they are not worried about anything at all and are happy:

children.name: chẳng lo lắng phiền muộn gì cả , vô tư
examples: ▪ I was just sixteen, young, confident and without a care in the world.
▪ He puffed away on his pipe as if he didn’t have a care in the world.

children.name: laugh off
children.definition: to laugh and refuse to worry or be serious about a problem, when someone is trying to talk to you about it:
examples: cười xòa ( khi người khác tỏ ra lo lắng )
laugh off something
▪ Venables laughed off suggestions that he will be asked to retire.
▪ She took praise with delight, and laughed off any criticisms with good humour.
laugh it off
▪ She was genuinely angry, but Luke just tried to laugh it off.

children.name: lo lắng
examples: ▪ My husband worries when I’m late home from work.
▪ Don’t worry, there’s plenty of time.
▪ Mom, stop worrying. I’ll be fine.

children.name: worry (that)
examples: ▪ He began to worry he might lose his job.
▪ I was worried that Shannon was too small, but the doctor says she’s fine.

children.name: worry about
examples: ▪ I was really worried about it at the time.
I don’t know what you’re worrying about.

children.name: fret
children.definition: to worrya lotabout something, especially something that isnotveryserious:

children.name: phiền muộn ( rất nhiều về điều gì không đáng )
examples: ▪ She worries and frets all the time -- I think it’s because she’s got no one to talk to about her problems.

children.name: fret about/over
examples: ▪ I’d sit in meetings, fretting about what was happening at home.
▪ There’s no point in fretting over it now.

children.name: fret that
examples: ▪ Opponents fret that the system might not provide enough help in times of rural economic crisis.

children.name: brood
children.definition: to keep thinking about and worrying about a problemfor a long timeafter ithashappened:

children.name: u mê , sầu bi ( 1 thời gian dài về điều gì đã xảy ra )
examples: ▪ There’s no point in brooding -- forget about her.
▪ Dad alternately brooded and raged, and Mum wasn’t much better.

children.name: brood about/over/on
examples: ▪ Don’t sit at home brooding about how badly you’ve been treated.
▪ Achilles sits in his tent, brooding over the wrongs done to him.

children.name: be worried sick
children.definition: to beveryworriedand upset about something:

children.name: rất lo lắng
examples: ▪ Where were you last night? I was worried sick.

children.name: be worried sick about
examples: ▪ She’s worried sick about the possibility of losing her job.
▪ I’m worried sick about Sandy. I haven’t heard from her for days.

children.name: worry yourself sick
examples: ▪ Jenny had worried herself sick trying to think of a way to pay back the money.

children.name: frantic
children.definition: extremelyworriedand frightened about a situation and unable to think or behave calmly:
examples: frantically[adverb]
▪ She hung on frantically, terrified by the steep drop below.

children.name: phát điên
examples: ▪ Inspector Grimes was used to dealing with frantic parents.

children.name: get/grow/become frantic
examples: ▪ The knocking on the door and shouts became frantic.
▪ There is still no news of the missing child and her parents are getting frantic.
▪ The dog’s barking grew frantic as I approached.

children.name: frantic with worry/fear
examples: ▪ Her eyes were frantic with fear, and she couldn’t keep still.

children.name: be at your wits’ end
children.definition: to beveryworried about a problem, especially something thathasbeenhappeningfor a long time that you feel you cannot deal with any longer:

children.name: hoang mang ( không biết xử lý thế nào về một vấn đễ đã diễn ra được một thời gian dài)
examples: ▪ I don’t know what I can do to keep our marriage together -- I’m at my wits’ end!
▪ It was two days before the baby was due, and Robert was at his wits’ end.

children.name: have qualms
children.definition: to be worried that something you are going to do might bemorallywrong:

children.name: áy náy, bứt rứt ( về việc sắp làm có thể sai trái )
examples: ▪ Few so-called animal lovers have qualms when they purchase meat from supermarkets.
▪ Despite my qualms, I accepted the job.

children.name: have qualms about
examples: ▪ Shareholders seem to have few qualms about companies sponsoring overseas abortion programs.

children.name: to feel worried all the time
have a lot on your mind
children.definition: to havea lot of problemsto worry about, especially when this means that you do not concentrate on other things:

children.name: có nhiều truyện phiền muộn ( ko thể tập trung vào việc gì )
examples: ▪ Since the divorce, Linda’s had a lot on her mind.
▪ I’m sorry I wasn’t paying attention, I have a lot on my mind at the moment.

children.name: be under stress/(a) strain
children.definition: be under stress/be under (a) strain  to have a lot of work to do or have a lot of problems to deal with, so that you feel worried and tired or get upset easily:

children.name: bị căng thẳng
examples: ▪ Although I was under a strain, and drinking a lot at the time, I remember very clearly what happened.
▪ This investigation has placed her under additional stress.

children.name: be under a lot of stress/strain
examples: ▪ Mr Payne, have you been under a lot of stress recently?

children.name: stressed out
children.definition: so worried and tired from problems you have to deal withcontinuouslythat you cannot relax:
examples: bị căng thẳng
▪ By the end of the tour, the band was totally stressed out.
▪ One of my adult students was a stressed-out working mother0
feel stressed out
▪ I’m trying to have a few early nights because I’m feeling stressed out at the moment.

children.name: preoccupied
children.definition: worrying so much about aparticularproblemthat you cannot think about anything else:

children.name: bận tâm , lo lắng ( về một việc nào đó đến nỗi không thể nghĩ đến việc khác )
examples: ▪ I admit I’m preoccupied and snappy at the moment -- I’m sorry.
▪ Alison had entered the room, but he was too preoccupied to notice.

children.name: look/seem preoccupied
examples: ▪ She seemed preoccupied and kept glancing toward the window.

children.name: preoccupied look/expression etc
examples: ▪ Prajapat glanced up with a preoccupied smile, then went back to the map.

children.name: preoccupied with
examples: ▪ He was far too preoccupied with his own marital difficulties to give any thought to his friend’s problems.

children.name: paranoid
children.definition: someone who is paranoid is worried all the timethat people do not like them, thatbadthingsare going to happen to them etc, when this isnottrue:
examples: hoang tưởng ( rằng mọi người không thích, điều gì xấu sắp xảy ra )
▪ I was so paranoid at one point, that I was refusing to answer the door.
feel paranoid
▪ The mysterious phone calls were beginning to make him feel paranoid.
paranoid about
▪ By 1982, he was so paranoid about his health that he wore plastic gloves at all times.
paranoia/ˌpærəˈnɔɪə/ [uncountable noun] the feeling or medical condition of being paranoid:
▪ Just forget it -- it’s pure paranoia.
▪ the paranoia of the Nixon years
somebody’s paranoia
▪ His words only added to her fear and paranoia.

children.name: tense
children.definition: asituationortimethat is tense makes you feel worried and nervous that something bad might happen at any time:

children.name: ( tình huống , thời điểm) căng thẳng
examples: ▪ The atmosphere in the waiting room was extremely tense.
▪ In the program, the hostages re-live the tense days they spent under guard in East Africa.
▪ In the tense silence that followed, the boys fidgeted uneasily.

children.name: tense face/expression etc : nét mặt, biểu hiện căng thẳng
examples: ▪ Her tone was anxious now, her face tense.

children.name: gây lo lắng
examples: ▪ The possibility that I might lose my job is very worrying.
▪ It must have been a worrying time for you.

children.name: it’s worrying that/when etc
examples: ▪ It’s always a little worrisome when a company is praised for making a smaller loss than expected.

children.name: stressful
children.definition: a stressfuljoborsituationmakes you feel worried and tired all the time, for example because you have too many problems or too much work to do:

children.name: căng thẳng
examples: ▪ Looking after small children can be very stressful.
▪ What’s the most stressful aspect of your job?
▪ It was a stressful time for the whole family.

children.name: anxious
examples: anxious time/wait/hours etc.a time during which you feel worried and nervous, because the situation is dangerous and you do not know what is going to happen:

children.name: thời gian, giấy phút.. lo âu
examples: ▪ For one anxious moment, I thought the rope was going to break.
▪ After an anxious wait, Audrey was told her father had died.
▪ In the anxious days that followed, Henry tried to keep his mind off his results.

children.name: alarming
children.definition: changing or increasing in a way that is worrying and frightening:
examples: gây hoang mang , lo sợ
▪ Even more alarming is the increase in child porn sites on the Internet.
▪ an alarming rise in crime
it’s alarming that/when etc
▪ It’s alarming to think how many people are at risk.
alarming rate/number
▪ The epidemic is spreading at an alarming rate.
▪ There are no easy answers to the alarming number of mass killings taking place in our cities.
in alarming numbers
▪ The young girls she treats in alarming numbers are the victims of broken homes and parental neglect.
at an alarming rate
▪ Agricultural open space is disappearing at an alarming rate.
with alarming frequency/regularity
▪ Baggage seems to go missing with alarming frequency on these flights.
alarmingly[adverb]
▪ Infant mortality among the population is alarmingly high.

children.name: niggling
examples: niggling feeling/worry/doubt etc : something that continues to worry you, even though you do not really want to think about it:

children.name: bứt rứt
examples: ▪ The suspect seemed to have proved his innocence, but a niggling doubt remained in my mind.
▪ I couldn’t shake off a niggling worry. Had I forgotten to lock the office door?

children.name: alarmist
children.definition: making people worried about dangers that do not really exist:

children.name: gây hoang mang sợ hãi
examples: ▪ I do not wish to be alarmist, but the situation in the region is worse than it has been in many months.
▪ The ambassador dismissed these views as excessively alarmist.

children.name: worrier
children.definition: the type of person who worries a lot, even when they do not need to:

children.name: người hay lo lắng
examples: ▪ He admitted to the doctor that he was a worrier and found it hard to relax.
▪ My grandmother was always a worrier, and I take after her.

children.name: worrywart
children.definition: informal someone who worries too much:

children.name: người hay lo lắng
examples: ▪ Don’t be such a worrywart!
▪ The cast also included Norman Fell as the worrywart producer.

children.name: neurotic
children.definition: always very worried and nervous aboutunimportantthings or about dangers that donotreallyexist:
examples: neurotic[countable noun]
▪ She is a complete neurotic - I don’t think I’ve ever seen her sit down and relax.

children.name: dễ bị tác động thần kinh
examples: ▪ He was a shy, neurotic man who found it difficult to make friends.
▪ In many respects, Mozart had a typically neurotic personality.

children.name: what you say to tell sb not to worry
don’t worry
examples: đừng lo lắng
▪ ‘Don’t worry, there’s plenty of food for anyone who wants to come.’
don’t worry about
▪ ‘Don’t worry about me -- I’ll be fine,’ said Billie.
▪ Don’t worry about it. You can pay me back tomorrow.

children.name: it’s/everything’s all right
children.definition: also it’s/everything’s ok  use this to try to make someone feel better when they are worrying:

children.name: Ổn thôi
examples: ▪ It’s all right, honey, don’t cry.
▪ It’ll all be over soon, and everything’s going to be ok.

children.name: nothing to worry about
children.definition: use this to tell someone that there is no reason to worry:
examples: chẳng có gì phải lo lắng cả
there’s/it’s nothing to worry about
▪ It’s just a simple check-up. There’s nothing to worry about.
somebody has nothing to worry about
▪ You’re a bright girl, and you’ve got nothing to worry about, as long as you finish all your assignments.
